journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: Calibration of a six-DOF parallel manipulator for chromosome dissection

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai, People’s Republic of China

author-notes.corresp: *State Key Laboratory of Mechanical System and Vibration, Shanghai Jiao Tong University, Shanghai 200240, People’s Republic of China. email: gaofengsjtu@gmail.com

abstract.p: This article proposes a calibration method for a six-PPPS parallel manipulator which is the macro-part of a dual-drive chromosome dissection system. The calibration model is built with respect to Denavit–Hartenberg notation. Certain adjustment matrices are utilized to provide independent error parameters. The pose of the moving platform as while as relative motion of all prismatic joints and spherical joints are measured by the latest API T3 laser tracker. Other than general methods that need reconstruction of the location and orientation of the platform with point coordinates, these data can be obtained directly within one single measurement in the proposed method. For data processing, a step-by-step calculation method has been presented to select initial error parameters. With this method, partial error parameters can be derived in advance to be substituted into the calibration model providing calculation efficiency superior to simultaneous computation. Simulation based on the geometry of this manipulator shows a decent convergence performance of the calibration model. The experimental results also validate the efficiency and the convenience of the proposed method.

sec.title: 1 INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Parallel robots, also called parallel kinematic machines (PKM), are closed-loop mechanisms presenting very good performances in terms of accuracy, rigidity, and ability to manipulate large loads [1]. Among the numerous performances of PKM, accuracy is one of the most common factors that can evaluate its performance. By means of kinematic calibration, the accuracy can be improved effectively and economically [2].

Existing calibration methods could be divided into three major categories. First is the external calibration method which relies on total or partial measurements of the moving platform pose parameters using external device. In this category, several measuring instruments are utilized such as laser tracker [3, 4], optical sensor [5], theodolite [6, 7], linear variable differential transformers [8–10], and inclinometer [11]. After collecting required geometry parameters, both direct kinematics and inverse kinematics can be used to form the constraint equations. For direct kinematics method, it has to be able to select the real solution corresponding to the calibration pose, since real solution is not always limited to one forparallel mechanisms. For inverse kinematics method, the real solution is usually straightforward for parallel mechanisms. Therefore, the error parameters of each leg can be solved independently, which can greatly simplify the calibration model.

Another category of kinematic calibration is self-calibration, also called auto-calibration, which rely on internal sensor acting on active joints or passive joints to measure geometry parameters [12–15]. Comparing with external calibration method, it has the advantages of omitting pose measurement andfacilitating error compensation. However, only partial parameters can be identified in this way, since internal sensor is unable to give the absolute location of the end-effector. Besides, adding extra sensors on an existing machine in reality is always another hard task.

The third category is constrained calibration. This method relies on applying proper motion constrains on the mechanism such as linear constrain or orientation constrain [16–18]. With these constraints, the end-effector loses certain degrees of freedom (DOF) to conduct restricted motions, and the constraint equations will reflect these changes. It requires less expensive measuring instrument than external calibration method; however, the deformation of the locking device may distort the calibration results. Furthermore, only those robots whose actuators are capable of working in passive model can use this method.

A state-of-the-art survey [19] also points out thatsingularity-based calibration and cable-based measuring systems promise good beginnings in inexpensive calibration methods and should be taken into account.

This article presents a highly efficient and widely applicable calibration method to improve the accuracy of parallel mechanisms. The proposed method belongs to external calibration that mentioned above. With the adoption of the SmartTRAK Sensor (STS) and API T3 laser tracker, the position (x, y, z) and rotation orientation (pitch, yaw, and roll) of the moving platform can be determined with a single laser tracker in one single measurement. Comparing with the conventional method which needs the coordinates of three non-collinear points to calculate the pose information, STS lets to reach the displacement resolution of 1 µm and the angular resolution of 3arc-s without the disruption of measurement noise. Moreover, the motions of all kinematic joints are also measured with API T3 laser tracker. Next, the calibration model is constructed with respect to a six-PPPS parallel manipulator, which is the macro-part of a biological robot for chromosome dissection. The error parameters are described with Denavit–Hartenberg (D–H) notation [20, 21] and connected with adjustment matrices which can eliminate the associated interaction. By substituting the calibration model with measured geometry data, the constrain equation based on inverse kinematics using Taylor formula in terms of the unknown parameters is linearized. All the error parameters are integrated into several groups to avoid causing singularity. Partial error parameters are calculated sequentially by measuring joint motions individually in advance due to the low efficiency of simultaneous computation. These pre-calculated error parameters can be substituted as initial values to calculate the rest error parameters. In that case, overall identification Jacobian matrix is block diagonal. Therefore, the error parameters of each leg can be calculated independently with least square method after cyclic iteration. In the end, both simulation and experiment show the effectiveness of the proposed method.

The remainder of this article is organized as follows. Next, the kinematic model is described. Then, the calibration method is analysed and then the simulation and experimental results are presented. Finally, conclusions are drawn.

sec.title: 2.1 Mechanism description
sec.p:
The six-DOF parallel manipulator which is used to illustrate the calibration method was first developed at Hebei University of Technology [22]. It is part of a Macro–micro dual-drive system for chromosome dissection using glass needle [23]. This system consists of macro- and micro-manipulators, end-effector, six-dimensional mouse, and inverted microscope, as shown in Fig. 1. The macro-part is responsible for sending the glass needle tip to the scope of objective lens. It has a stroke of 106 mm in three directions and a rotation angle of 37.4° about each axis. Its kinematic architecture is presented in Fig. 2. The orthogonal structure includes six identical parallel chains which will be further referred as ‘limb’. Each limb is formally described as PPPS-chain, where P and S denote prismatic and spherical joints, respectively. For each limb, the first P joint is an active joint followed by two passive P joints with mutually orthogonal axes. Then, the equivalent S joint composed of three revolute joints (R joints) connects the moving platform. These limbs are divided into three groups. Each group consists of two parallel limbs, and the three groups also lay in orthogonal directions. The end-effector is connected to these three groups in such a manner that it provides translational and rotational motions. Since the stroke of the micro-manipulator is 30 µm in each direction, the precision for the macro-manipulator should be better than that. Fig. 1
The macro–micro dual-drive system for chromosome dissection Fig. 2
The kinematic architecture of six-PPPS parallel manipulator

The centre of the fixed coordinate system F is located next to the manipulator on the vibration isolation platform. The moving coordinate system M lies at the centre of the moving platform which is also the conjunction of three groups of limbs. At initial position, coordinates F and M share the same orientation while each axis parallel to its corresponding limb. Each of the six limbs is connected to the moving platform at point Si via S joint. The actuator acts on the other side of the limb via the active P joint. qi denotes the input displacement of limb i and (c1 i,c2 i) the displacements of passive P joints along three coordinate axes (in the remainder of this article, i = 1, 2, …, 6 represent the number of limbs). a is the distance between the centre of frame M and the lineation of two linked S joints. b is the distance between two linked S joints. All the parameters are defined with respect to the initial position.

By analysing the constraint of six S joints, one can derive the forward and inverse kinematic relations of the moving platform [24]. The result shows that this macro-manipulator is decoupled from translational aspect. Since the structure of each pair of limbs in three axes is of the same, it is isotropic theoretically disregarding the impact of gravity. Moreover, the isotropic structure can simplify the calibration modelling process from building a six-limb direct kinematic model to a single-limb inverse kinematic model.

sec.title: 2.2 Modelling assumption
sec.p:
This method is based on the following modelling assumptions.
The components of the manipulator are of all rigid bodies without deformation [25] during the motion process.
All spherical joints are assumed to be perfect.
The default location (zero position) is defined theoretically. Its corresponding pose error is treated as the offset to be estimated.
Measurement errors are not considered.
Joint clearance is treated as random error [26].

sec.title: 2.3 Kinematic model
sec.p: Since the error parameters of each limb can be calibrated independently, D–H method is used [27] to define error parameters. It is a well-established method that can describe the link transformations from joint to joint with identical form. For one transformation matrix, there are four parameters, namely link offset, di, joint angle, θi, link length, ai-1, and link twist, αi-1. The general form of the link transformation matrix from frame i-1 to frame i is shown in equation (1). Given the probability of bring un-independent parameters, the method for eliminating them will be introduced in Section 3 (1)

As mentioned above, the calibration models for all six limbs are identical with regard to expression. Therefore, the transformation matrices for only one limb can illustrate the whole model. Figure 3 shows the transformation coordinates assigned to limb 3. Fig. 3
The frame assignment for limb 3

Fixed coordinate {F} locates on the vibration isolator on which the manipulator is placed. Moving coordinate {M} is fixed on the centre of the moving platform. Base coordinates {Bi} lay in the conjunction between each motor axis i and its corresponding lead screw. Its link transformation from coordinate {F} is denoted as FAB i and shown in Table 1 describing with X–Y–Z fixed angles. In the rest of the tables, angular units are radian and length units millimetre if there is no specification. Table 1
The initial values of FAB i
i Rz Ry Rx X Y Z
1 0 −π/2 π 396 −295 −272
2 0 −π/2 π 396 −459 −272
3 0 0 −π/2 884 −865 −190
4 0 0 −π/2 884 −865 −354
5 π/2 0 0 966 −377 −760
6 π/2 0 0 802 −377 −760

The link transformation matrices containing error parameters within each limb are described as Ak i using D–H matrix in Table 2. The superscript i represents link number while the subscript k matrix number. These matrices share the same form but different error parameters indicated as Δθj i, Δdj i, Δaj-1 i, and Δαj-1 i where j represents the coordinate number assigned in Fig. 3. Please be aware that the angular parameters are the same while k equals 1&3, 5&7, 9&11 and 16&17. Since the error parameters will be calculated step by step in Section 3, the previously calculated angular error parameters will affect the length error parameters in the rear links. Therefore, these matrices are used to eliminate the influence acting from the angular error parameters in current link to rear links. Table 2
Link parameters of limb i
k j αj-1 i aj-1 i dj i θj i
1 1 Δα0 i Δa0 i 215 + Δd1 i Δθ1 i
2 1 0 0 qi 0
3 1 Δα0 i 0 0 Δθ1 i
5 2 Δα1 i Δa1 i Δd2 i Δθ2 i
6 2 0 0 c1 i 0
7 2 Δα1 i 0 0 Δθ2 i
9 3 Δα2 i Δa2 i Δd3 i Δθ3 i
10 3 0 0 c2 i 0
11 3 Δα2 i 0 0 Δθ3 i
13 4 Δα3 i Δa3 i Δd4 i Δθ4 i
16 5 Δα4 i Δa4 i Δd5 i Δθ5 i
17 5 Δα4 i 0 0 Δθ5 i

One cannot express each link transformation with only one matrix when three Z axes are perpendicular to each other because that will lead to conflict on axis assignment. Therefore, one multiplies several other matrices within the transformation for the proposed orthogonal structure. Some of these matrices are identical for all limbs such as Ak i(k=4,8) in Table 3 describing with X–Y–Z fixed angles, while some of these differ with limbs such as A12 i shown in Table 4. Table 3
Link parameters of A4 i and A8 i
Rz Ry Rx X Y Z
A4 i 0 −π/2 −π/2 0 0 16
A8 i 0 0 −π/2 93 0 0
Table 4
Link parameters of A12 i
i Rz Ry Rx X Y Z
1&2 0 0 0 0 0 0
3&4 0 −π/2 −π/2 0 0 0
5&6 π/2 0 −π/2 0 0 0

A15 i is the transformation matrix from Si to the centre of the moving platform. It also differs with limbs and shown is in Table 5. Partial measurement data are also included in the model to increase the precision such as A14 i and AM i. A14 i is the rotation matrix of S joint for limb i representing the relative angular change. It can be calculated with the pose parameters of the moving platform. AM i is the installation offset of the moving platform with respect to the fixed coordinate. In the end, the transformation from coordinate {F} to coordinate {M} through limb i can be expressed as shown below (2) Table 5
Link parameters of A15 i
i Rz Ry Rx X Y Z
1 0 0 0 164 −82 0
2 0 0 0 164 82 0
3 0 0 0 0 164 −82
4 0 0 0 0 164 82
5 0 0 0 −82 0 164
6 0 0 0 82 0 164
In equation (2), the transformation matrices (Ak i)-1(k=3,7,11,17) are used to eliminate the impacts of cumulated angular errors from previous parts as it is mentioned above.

Next, one uses Euler(ϕ,θ,ψ,)=Rot(Z,ϕ) Rot(Y, θ) Rot(Z, ψ) to describe the pose of the moving platform during calibration. The pose configuration in Section 4 will prevent it from being singularity. Then, it can be written compactly as (3)

For convenient calculation, the equations above are linearized by Taylor formula. The displacement results such as X, Y, and Z are shown in the form of equation (4). f is a symbol which could be any one of the pose parameters in equation (3). f(PARi) describes the equation f in which all the variables are substituted with initial error parameters. The angular results are presented in equations (5) to (7) separately with the first-order Taylor expansion. PARi is the set of all initial error parameters like (Δθj i)0, (Δdj i)0, (Δaj-1 i)0, and (Δαj-1 i)0 for limb i (4) (5) (6) (7)

Thus, one can get six linearized equations from one pose with respect to X, Y, Z, θ, ψ, ϕ. Each equation contains 20 unidentified parameters. Since some of them are un-independent error parameters, one will eliminate it to 14 in Section 3. Then, one uses n calibration poses to create 6n equations for each limb. After sorting, the equations for one limb with error parameters can be simplified as shown below (8) where [ΔθΔdΔaΔα]14x1T represents the array of Δθj i, Δdj i, Δaj-1 i and Δαj-1 i. A6nx14 is the corresponding Jacobean matrix. B6nx1 is the rest parts from equation (4) and (7). Applying the least square method to equation (8), one can get (9)
Finally, the results can be calculated using cyclic iteration.

sec.title: 3 KINEMATIC CALIBRATION METHOD
sec.p:
By analysing the difference between the theoretical output and actual output, one can identify all the error parameters. The calibration procedure can be summarized as follows.
Choose appropriate poses. The quality of the calibration result is greatly influenced by the set of selected poses [28]. It is generally accepted that the use of redundant poses is essential to improve the calibration process to average modelling and measuring errors. However, it is unclear that adding calibration poses as much as possible can lead to better solution. By analysing the observation matrix with different pose numbers, one decides to use nine calibration poses corresponding to the moving coordinate M where qi = 0 for an acceptable convergence speed with decent iteration result. The detailed pose selection is listed in the simulation section.
Measure the displacements of all P joints in each limb. According to the calibration model, the relative displacements of all P joints are needed in the calculation of error parameters.
Measure the pose of the moving platform. The pose information is measured with respect to thefixed coordinate system. These data can also be used to calculate the rotation of S joints.
Search optimal parameters that satisfied the requirement of precision. The detailed calculation process is shown in Fig. 4.
Fig. 4
Flowchart of the calculation procedure

The selection of the initial values of error parameters is very critical in the whole calibration process. A decent searching range can not only increase the convergence speed but also improve the precision of the solution. Moreover, these values can be set according to the analysis of the measurement rather than arbitrary values within possible limits.

As it is mentioned above, the starting and the end positions of P joints are measured during the measurement process. By analysing equation (2), one can see that relative position changes of P joints (Δqx i, Δqy i, Δqz i), (Δc1x i, Δc1y i, Δc1z i), and (Δc2x i, Δc2y i, Δc2z i) are the variables of FAM i. Therefore, partial error parameters can be calculated in advance using the same method that was mentioned above as the initial parameters. The corresponding relationship of Δθ1 i, Δd1 i, Δa0 i, and Δα0 i are shown in equation (10) (10)

By analysing equation (10) one can get Δθ1 i and Δα0 i as the calibration result cause Δd1 i and Δa0 i have no impact on the relative changes. Then, one substitutes them into equation (11) below to calculate Δθ2 i, Δd2 i, Δa1 i, and Δα1 i. (11)
Only angular parameters Δθ2 i and Δα1 i can bederived for the same reason that was mentionedabove. Then, one substitutes them to equation (12) below to calculate Δθ3 i, Δd3 i, Δa2 i, and Δα2 i (12)

To summarize, only angular error parameters like Δθ1 i, Δθ2 i, Δθ3 i, Δα0 i, Δα1 i, and Δα2 i can be calculated using relative position changes of P joints. However, these previously substituted parameters will increase the convergence speed dramatically in the final calculation. Besides, one finds that some parameters only influence the model as a group during the preliminary research, though the group assignment differed with limbs. The coefficients of these parameters in the linearized equations are the same while they act as a group. Therefore, one combines these parameters into several groups and use only one parameter for each group to describe their group influence. Thus, one reduces the number of unidentified parameters from 20 to 14 for each limb and the detailed distribution is reflected in Section 4. This reduction can also be calculated by the equation for calculating the number of the independent parameters proposed by Legnani [29].

sec.title: 4.1 Simulation results
sec.p:
The simulation is conducted with MATLAB using 9 calibration poses in Table 6. The corresponding observation matrix built with respect to limb 3 using equation 8 is verified to be full rank that meets the calculation condition of least square method. Different poses do affect the calibration result. Since different poses will cause different displacements of P joints, the coefficients in the linearized equations will be changed, and so does the iteration procedure. However one cannot tell exactly how big the influences are while it is a pure mathematic problem about finding the difference between two equations with different but relevant coefficients. These analyses will be conducted in our next paper regarding accuracy analysis. Table 6
Calibration poses
No. 1 2 3 4 5 6 7 8 9
X (mm) 25 25 25 30 30 30 30 30 30
Y (mm) 35 35 35 40 40 40 30 30 30
Z (mm) 45 45 45 50 50 50 30 30 30
Rx (degrees) 12 0 0 10 0 0 5 0 0
Ry (degrees) 0 12 0 0 10 0 0 5 0
Rz (degrees) 0 0 12 0 0 10 0 0 5

The detailed assignment of poses is restricted by the stroke limitation of the macro-manipulator in each direction. Moreover, the displacements of each actuator are also considered to make the coefficients of error parameters in the linearized equation being of the same order of magnitude while calculation. Finally, one tries to actuate the active P joints as much as possible to cover most of its workspace; so, one can get even performances at all positions after calibration. If the actuations of the active P joints do not cover most of their strokes, the calibration results may only reflect part of its working space. Then, the quality of the calibration will depends on the linearity of the joints. Considering all the points mentioned above, one lets the moving platform to reach the middle position based on its stroke limitation and rotate about three axes with the same angle as big as possible separately to get the first three poses. Then, one decreases the rotation angle to get longer translational displacement to get another three poses. Finally, one decreases the rotation angle along with the translational displacement to get the last three poses.

In order to show the convergence clearly, all the angular error parameters are set to be 0.1° and all the length error parameters are set to be 0.1 mm. The initial values of all parameters have a ±10 per cent random offset based on set values. The convergence of all error parameters is shown in Fig. 5 which can prove the effectiveness of the proposed method. Fig. 5
The convergence of all error parameters in simulation

Furthermore, the comparison between the proposed method and the common method with respect to time consumption is illustrated in Table 7. The computer which is used to conduct the calculation has an Inter(R) Core(TM)2 Duo E7200 processor at 2.53 GHz with 2.00 GB RAM. It shows that the common method needs 14 min to go through one iteration, while our proposed method needs only 2.2 min. The iteration times vary while the calculated error parameters get convergent. It takes less than six times for the first three steps, respectively, and almost 50 times for the last step using the proposed method. On contrary, the result is still divergent after 80 times iteration for the common method. Considering the convergence speed, the overall time consumption is lesser for the proposed method. Table 7
Comparison of time consumption for one iteration
Parameters Δθ1 i, Δα0 i Δθ2 i, Δα1 i Δθ3 i, Δα2 i The rest
Proposed method 2 s 4 s 5 s 122 s
Common method 14 min 3 s

sec.title: 4.2 Experimental results
sec.p:
Experiments are also conducted in this article to validate the efficiency and generality of the proposedcalibration method for parallel mechanisms. Asmentioned above, API T3 laser tracker and STS are employed to measure the pose of the moving platform and the relative coordinate changes of each passive P joint and S joint. As shown in Fig. 6, three adapters are mounted on the P joints separately in one limb while STS is fixed on the moving platform. The spherically mounted retro reflector (SMR) can be moved from one adapter to another to measure the position of the corresponding P joint. The pose of the moving platform can be measured directly with STS. Then, the relative changes of S joints can be calculated with the rotation part of these pose information. During the experiment, one goes through all nine poses that are the same as simulation and measure the data with respect to one limb at a time including the displacements of three P joints and the pose of the moving platform. Then, one puts the adapters on the rest of the limbs and measure the data one after another. Fig. 6
Measurement devices (a) SMR and three adapters (b) STS

As one can see that the position of nonzero error parameters in each limb is different. However, when one tries to fix the position of the nonzero parameters, their coefficients in the linearized equation become too high and ruin the result. The following explanation might be the reason. Since FAB i and A15 i are different in each limb, the coefficients of the error parameters are different. Therefore, MATLAB would sort the position of nonzero parameters to fit the result with respect to the least square method. Moreover, to meet the definition of D–H matrix, certain rotation matrices have to be added in the equation due to the orthogonal structure of this particular mechanism. Since the pre-calculation of partial error parameters is based on relative position changes of P joints, the angular parameters α and θ in one transformation matrix are somehow not that precise as a single parameter in the fitting process, even though they act good as a whole with respect to the least square method. Then, the link length will magnify the impact acting on the length error parameters from the angular parameters. Therefore, some values that are presented as the combination of several other errors are relatively higher than the others.

In order to verify the improvement in the positioning accuracy of this six-PPPS parallel manipulator after calibration, the nominal and identified kinematic parameters are used in the control model separately. The moving platform is ordered to translate along three axes with 5 mm each time at a constant speed of 1 mm/s with the acceleration of 4 mm/s2. Figure 7 shows the differences between commanded and actual positions along three axes before and after calibration. The results show the accuracy (mean error with standard deviation) of 11.41 ± 6.58, 12.69 ± 6.23, and −6.66 ± 21.25 µm before calibration and 0.34 ± 9.17 µm, −3.05 ± 4.53 µm, and −5.79 ± 12.72 µm after calibration for the three-dimensional (3-D) positioning with respect to each axis. The Student’s t-test is also conducted. The correspondingt-values are 3.101 6, 6.461 8, and 0.111 1. The p-values less than 0.02 for X- and Y-axes indicate statistical significance but more than 0.5 for Z-axis shows statistical insignificance. This is mainly caused by the deformation along Z-axis since the mass of the moving platform is only acted on that axis. Fig. 7
The absolute differences between commanded and actual positions

Similarly, the moving platform is also ordered to rotate about the X-, Y-, and Z-axes of the moving coordinate at initial position to verify the improvement in angular accuracy. Figure 8 shows the angular differences between commanded pose and actual pose along three axes before and after calibration. The accuracies (mean error with standard deviation) are of −0.38 ± 3.87′, −0.15 ± 4.59′, and −0.31 ± 1.11’ before calibration and −0.05 ± 0.46′, −0.11 ± 0.24′, and 0.12 ± 0.21′ after calibration for the 3-D rotation about each axis. The Student’s t-test is also conducted. The corresponding t-values are 0.267 8, 0.027 5, and 1.203 7. The p-values are more than 0.5 for X- and Y-axes but less than 0.5 for Z-axis. Although the t-test indicates statistical insignificance, the improvement of precision is significant. Fig. 8
The angular differences between commanded and actual poses

sec.title: 5 CONCLUSIONS
sec.p: This article presented a calibration method for parallel mechanisms that can be widely applied to minimize the efforts on data measurement and improve calculation efficiency. For the six-PPPS parallel manipulator, one used to imply the proposed calibration method, the motions of the P joints as while as the moving platform have been measured with API T3 laser tracker conveniently. All the error parameters are defined with D–H notation. The interactions among these parameters are eliminated by adjustment matrices. These matrices are inverse matrices of the previous angular transformation matrices containing angular error parameters. The angular error parameters of P joints are variables of the relative displacement equations of the corresponding P joints. Thus, they can be derived sequentially in advance as the initial error parameters to increase the speed of iteration process. The experiment shows that the time consumption for the proposed method is six times less than the traditional one. After cyclic iteration, totally 84 error parameters have been calculated. Both simulation and experiment demonstrate the effectiveness of this method.

sec.title: FUNDING
sec.p: This study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China (grant nos 30770538 and 50821003); the State Key Program of National Natural Science of China (grant no. 60534020); and the Joint Research Fund for Overseas Natural Science of China (grant no. 50728503).
